text.*:
This is a partial list of works that use metafictional ideas. Metafiction is intentional allusion or reference to a work's fictional nature. It is commonly used for humourous or parodic effect, and has appeared in a wide range of mediums, including writing, film, theatre, and video gaming.

Contents

  • 1 Novels, novellas and short stories
    • 1.1 Pre-20th century works
    • 1.2 Modern and contemporary works
    • 1.3 Children's books and young adult fiction
  • 2 Animated short films
  • 3 Stage plays
    • 3.1 Pre-20th century works
    • 3.2 Modern works
    • 3.3 Musicals
  • 4 Films
  • 5 Television shows
  • 6 Comic strips, comic books and graphic novels
  • 7 Interactive media and video games
  • 8 Web videos
    • 8.1 Multiple authors
  • 9 Artists' books
  • 10 References

Novels, novellas and short stories[edit]

See also: Category:Metafictional works

Pre-20th century works[edit]

  • Laurence Sterne, The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman
  • William Makepeace Thackeray, Vanity Fair

  • To Boldly Flee

  • Cracked.com
  • I'm a Marvel and I'm a DC

Multiple authors[edit]

  • The Marvel Comics characters Deadpool, Uatu the Watcher, Spider-Ham, Howard the Duck and Purple Man are all aware they are in a comic book.
  • The DC Comics characters Ambush Bug and The Joker are aware that they are in a comic book.
  • Penny Arcade frequently features metafiction, particularly their fantasy setting Epic Legends of the Hierarchs: The Elemenstor Saga, which has a detailed wiki devoted to it.
  • The Ongoing Adventures of Rocket Llama is fiction with a metafictional history.
  • Triangle and Robert is heavily metafictional.

Artists' books[edit]

  • Space Opera: The Artist's Book by Michael J. Weller
